Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant met the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 551 days
Traveled frequently between Canada and Colombia
Court_Ruling: Citizenship judge's decision was reasonable and upheld
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Lack of centralization of mode of existence in Canada
Assessment_Factor: Ties to Canada vs. foreign country
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged, but conduct raised doubts about residency intent
Evidence_Used: Travel records showing 551 days of absence
Frequency and duration of international travel
Application_Basis: Physical presence and mode of existence in Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturn of citizenship refusal and approval of application
Governing_Rule: Applicant must be physically present in Canada for 1095 days in the 4 years preceding application and demonstrate centralization of mode of existence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to prove temporary nature of absences
Insufficient demonstration of primary residence in Canada
Outcome: Applicant remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Harm_Assessment: No harm to public interest; integrity of citizenship process maintained
Cause_Description: Applicant's frequent absences and strong business ties to Colombia indicated that Canada was not the central place of his mode of existence
Evidence_Handling: Travel and business records analyzed under Koo (Re) framework
Evidence_Issues: Absence records and foreign business ownership used to infer lack of residency
Residency_Compliance: Not satisfied â€“ failed both physical presence and mode of existence tests
Evidence_Assessment: Absences deemed structural, not temporary; foreign ties outweighed Canadian connections
Decision_Rationale: The pattern of absences and economic engagement in Colombia demonstrated that the applicant did not fulfill the residency requirement
Evidentiary_Issues: No dispute over evidence; interpretation focused on meaning of absences
